content.content: I thought the same: why can’t a bunch be used to buy U.S. Treasury Bills (can be bought and held directly and electronically, shouldn’t be a violation of '40 Act), for example.  The answer when I asked - no way to own it and no way to control embezzlement.  The embezzlement part, I would think one could set up something that required 3 or more people (or smart contracts) to “key” a sale or transfer.  The ownership part is a puzzle with an autonomous organization.  And I think the question becomes are MKR holders willing to cross the line to have some entity form so that those kind of asset purchases could be done. Arca Labs was trying to do a tokenized interest in a T-Bill fund, maybe they have been successful, but a fund is not what we would want because an interest in it would lose value as interest rates went up. Because the USDC in the PSM represents collateral backing DAI we wouldn’t/shouldn’t burn MKR bought that way, it would have to be held, and MKR is a bit (!) more volatile than USDC.  Nice idea though - if there was a valid way to burn MKR I’m for it.

Hi folx, I wanted to share my perspective on investing USDC held in the PSM. While it would be great to earn additional income from this collateral, there are serious drawbacks to the available investments. Our immediate options for USDC can be broken down into two categories: lending (eg. Aave, Compound, Circle Yield, etc) and stablecoin AMMs (Curve, Uniswap v3, etc). Yearn vaults and other strategies generally represent a mix of these two yield sources. Lending - All else equal, supplying USDC to lending platforms like Aave or Compound will lead to lower borrowing rates on these platforms. Borrowers currently using Maker’s crypto collateralized vaults will have an incentive to refinance their loans to take advantage of lower rates. This will reduce DAI supply, placing further pressure on the PSM and forcing MakerDAO to lower rates to remain competitive. Circle’s Yield product for USDC term deposits will have a similar effect - funds are lent out to crypto lending desks, and this liquidity ultimately competes with Maker’s crypto vaults and pushes down borrowing rates. Stablecoin AMMs - Automated market makers price assets based on the relative quantity of supplied funds within a pool. For example, if we supplied the PSM’s USDC to Curve, the DAI supplied to Curve would need to increase by a similar amount to maintain a stable price peg. This increase in DAI demand would counteract the benefits of the PSM and likely lead to even more USDC exposure. For both lending and AMM investments, using the USDC to earn yield causes increasing supply/demand imbalance and has the potential to cannibalize MakerDAO’s core vault lending revenues. So while I’d love to earn more on this pool of assets I don’t think it’s realistic. To reduce risk for USDC collateral and increase risk compensation, I think we should focus on the following areas instead of direct USDC investments: Interest rate reductions - The PPG-OMC-1 rates proposal group has already recommended sizable rate cuts for our crypto vault types, which are live for an executive vote here. We can pursue further rate cuts depending on how the markets respond to these initial changes. Over time this should help increase DAI supply and reduce USDC held in the PSM. New PSMs for other stablecoins - The community is considering adding additional PSMs for other stablecoins. Based on an initial signal request, it seems the community favors accepting BUSD, PAX, and GUSD. This will allow Maker to diversify its credit and counterparty risk among multiple issuers, helping address the negative perception of DAI becoming a USDC wrapper. Offering additional PSMs can also help Maker increase our “trading income” from PSM fees. Instead of only offering trading between DAI and USDC, we’ll now be able to offer trading between all of the PSM supported stablecoins, including trades that only use DAI as a bridging asset (eg. USDC<>PAX). Trading fees will likely remain low but could see some improvement versus the current state. New large cap collateral assets - Adding support for high potential crypto collaterals can help us meet DAI demand without as much reliance on fiat stablecoins. Top potential additions include Sushiswap LPs, xSUSHI, stETH, Curve LPs, and certain other large cap cryptos. Real world asset (RWA) backed lending - While it will take time to scale this up, this offers a vast potential source of DAI supply that can help us reduce reliance on USDC while earning a better risk adjusted return. I like the idea of investing funds into off chain cash assets like US treasury securities in principle, but this is unlikely to work in the current low rate environment because the additional custody risks and costs will outweigh any yield earned.

Expanding on that from my understanding the main risk in all of these stablecoins really boils down to one of two things that may one day happen   Insolvency risk / Counterparty Risk - eventually an actor would no longer be redeem said stablecoin for actual 1 USD.  Blacklist Risk - the stablecoin issuer (or potentially some external entity strong-arming the stablecoin issuer) decides that they don’t like what is going on with the PSM and then blacklists the PSM contract such that the stablecoin stored there cannot be withdrawn.  Not much maker can do about insolvency, but in moving all this collateral to a AMM you shift the later risk a bit. This is because blacklisting means that major trading venues effectively get shutdown. As I see it you basically can adopt a MAD doctrine in regard to the asset held such that both parties will incur loss of trust in their respective collateral if blacklisting is enacted. Which would mitigate your risk to some degree, but admittedly its hard to quantify.

content.content: monet-supply:  Stablecoin AMMs - Automated market makers price assets based on the relative quantity of supplied funds within a pool. For example, if we supplied the PSM’s USDC to Curve, the DAI supplied to Curve would need to increase by a similar amount to maintain a stable price peg. This increase in DAI demand would counteract the benefits of the PSM and likely lead to even more USDC exposure.   I’m not sure this is entirely correct (or more, it is correct, but it’s incomplete.) If we did take the PSM USDC and drop into into curve or UniV3 1-sided, then yes, we increase the pressure on the peg, and nullify the action. However, what we can actually do here is mint an amount of DAI equal to the amount of USDC in the PSM and put both into an AMM and take the LP/NFT tokens as collateral. Although this minted DAI may seem unbacked, it is still owned by the Maker Protocol, and it can only be accessed by other entities via depositing USDC in the AMM in exchange for DAI. Thus, any DAI that enters circulation becomes backed by the USDC that is exchanged for it - until that point it is owned by the protocol and is net-neutral to the balance sheet. In practice this means that we take Curve LP or UniV3 LP tokens as collateral which does result in the blacklist risk being one step removed from the Maker Protocol and allows us to collect fees on AMM trades. The negative effect here is that in the event of emergency shutdown, it becomes more awkward for users to redeem DAI for the underlying assets (due to the need for recursive redemptions) but DAI Holders can still access $1 worth of value for each DAI they hold.

content.content: What happened to the term lending module? That would probably get some traction if it were marketed correctly.

How did the call go? I have been following this thread with such interest, I finally decided to make an account. I believe there has to be some sort of arrangement that would be in both Maker’s and Circle’s best interests. Certainly, Circle is going to have the know-how, contacts, and framework (regulatory and otherwise) to deploy their stable coins to produce income that would take us a prohibitive amount of time to develop in the near-future. And it’s in their interest too as evidenced by the fact that they are promoting this in order to create new revenue streams and generate demand for their coin. I do not think they could afford to say ‘no’ to working with us to fill whatever their liquidity needs are that prompted this project in the first place. As noted:     PaperImperium:  Given that we now have ~10% of all USDC, I wonder if we could just ask USDC to remit us part of the interest they earn on the fiat backing it. I’m sure they couldn’t cough up $2.4 billion if we tried to redeem.   IMHO as long as we are in this USDC quagmire, as we seemingly will be for the immediate future, there aren’t really any additional risks to “banking” with Circle. And there are definitely fewer risks than keeping our USDC balance and depositing it on any other DeFi platform. In the latter case, cross-party risk is between two parties; in the former, multiple (even if they are working with Genesis &c, we’re pretty much assuming the risk of Circle’s failure anyway). I am exceedingly interested to know what Circle can come to the table with as I imagine it is a lot. And it needn’t necessarily be lending.
